title: Hey Duggee Badges
cardDescription: Watching Hey Duggee with my 1-year-old I thought how hard would it be to crochet the badges given by Duggee...
description: Hey Duggee is one my 1-year-olds favourite shows at the moment. I already made him Duggee and the cute frog. Next I began thinking if I could make the badges.

content.content: As with many of my projects, this one also started with a thought 'Could I crochet those...`'. I might do rest of the badges, or this might be all for now. We'll see.

All badges have an outer edge of 48 stitches. This is because the original badges from the show have 24 sections at their outer edge when sewn in place. So if you sew these badges, sew around every other stitch to achieve exactly the correct look.
Also when sewing in place, make sure to use the correct color!
You can find the list of all the badges here:

There aren't really special stitches but many badge details use a lot of color changes. With these it's important that when making a yellow stitch, you already have yellow yarn on your hook. Which means pulling through the _previous_ stitch with yellow yarn even though the stitch might be of another color.
Similarly when using multiple colors, take care to always keep the ends of yarns on the wrong side of the work.
Don't stress too much about finding the correct colors. I can be quite neurotic to find a color that matches the original as closely as possible, but you don't need to.
More important than choosing the right shade of yellow for example, is to select different shades of yellow that work together if the badge uses multiple yellow colors.
I tried choosing a size for the badges that makes them realistic sizes to actually be able to use. While also allowing enough detail for the badge image to be recognizable.
Still some images can be hard to make perfectly. So some imagination might be requried to see the result.
Naturally using finer yarn and smaller hook or using more embroidery can make badges more detailed. But I chose to do as much detail as I can while using the same weight yarn throughout.
